comments.commentBody: Funny, it seems like most commenters think a strong, centralized EU is possible. The lesson to be learned from this crisis is to cash out a weak participant like Greece, it is curtains for them without a devaluation. Or you can jointly issue bonds. Thinking that solidarity is going to come from disfunction is just utopian musing.

I am outraged.

The oil industry and weapons industry have won again.

And no matter what number the government PR hacks use for 'the number of troops on the ground' it will be misleadingly low . Two numbers must be watched: the number of Americans in the country being paid for by the U.S taxpayer, and the total number of people in the country being paid for by the U.S taxpayer.
Who cares?  These CEOs are the biggest collection of takers and con artists every assembled.  It is time for a revolution!!!

Their name is an acronym they should have heeded:

You Always Have Other Options!

To all USPS employees:

If you don’t like the job, pay and benefits: quit.

There are about 14 million unemployed Americans that would probably love to have your jobs even without the ridiculous retirement benefits.

The shallow talent pool argument maybe holds some water against the likes of Brazil or Germany.  But Belgium?  Seriously?  If we can't compete against Belgium (or Costa Rica, or other nations that weren't even in the last World Cup) we may as well give up now.

ESPN has done this twice now. Last time they bumped US v. MEX for a little league game. How insulting. Some supporter of US Soccer they are....

Brek Shea was clearly our best player and the only others who seemed like they came to play were Howard, Dempsey, Cherundolo, and Agudelo. I thought Goodson was very poor passing out of the back. No creativity in midfield for most of the match. I don't think Jozy or Juan are good enough being solo in this formation but maybe it will take time for this 4-3-3 to take shape as it still looks like a 4-5-1 to me. Holden could make a difference. However Jurgy wants creative attacking players and we don't have those players yet...maybe in another 5-10 yrs but not enough of them in the Nat Team player pool now.
Just who over at ESPN do we need to complain to about the last-minute switch to ESPN2?  It was truly a disservice to thousands of fans like myself who set their DVR to record the game.

Paul #1

"When you talent pool is thin, and you're evaluating it, wins will be sparse.
There is just no chance to be even top 20 in the world with this group.
Why on earth did Jurgen take the job."

I could not disagree more. The NYT writers like to cock a snoot and condescend to US soccer, we're not talented enough, Europeans are SOOO much better than we are, but you shouldn't take that too seriously.

Klinsman is doing an excellent job. Players who were nowhere under Bradley are now looking capable of playing on a world stage. The Times emphasizes that we have only scored one goal in three matches, but what is more important to me is that we have only given up three. We gave up four to Mexico in the Gold Cup final. A flat four and no Bornstein is already working wonders. Remember the early goals in every game in South Africa? Where are they now? With a decent defense we are in every match we play.

Klinsman is trying lots of different players in lots of different positions, which is exactly what he should be doing at this point in the cycle. He is clearly developing young and new players who will be able to join the holdovers from the last World Cup at the next one. We played without Dempsey against Costa Rica and without Donovan today and took a one goal loss each time. Klinsman is going to have to give up on the lone striker and go to a 2-4-4 sooner or later and the sooner he does the better the team will look.

Think what our lineup might look like next spring, Altidore, Agudelo, Dempsey, Donovan, Torres, Shea, Edu, Bradley, Beckerman, Bocanegro, Cherundulo, Howard. We're still short two defensemen and we will have to decide where the offensive players go, and who sits. But this could be much more than a top 20 team.

MNT might get all the press, but it certainly isn't at the same level of competitiveness as WNT.

"Belgium’s skillful control"?? HA HA. You won't find these delusions of grandeur in the women's game (the writers, not the players).

The difference that seems apparent to me is that better teams like Belgium have creativity, skill, and quick ball movement in front of the goal. The moment the US gets near the box, it gets stagnant. Robbie Rogers always seems to be one step behind, always late reactions. Altidore is tough and strong, but somewhat clumsy on his own (and often tired). Shea is showing creativity. Agudelo = wild and young.

Is Freddy the only American that is able to work with the space in front of the goal with skill? Donovan and Dempsey at times, but they're old and we need a future. Maybe Klinsmann should get a start.

It's so hard to believe that in such an athletic country like ours, it's hard to find the skill necessary to score goals in soccer. A testament to the greatness of the game.

My problem with Google Maps is the incredibly poor quality of many of their streetview pictures.  I know they can produce excellent quality pictures because I see them out there.  So why are some so poor.  Some are so bad I wonder why they bothered.  There is an option to report problems so I sent in several horrendous examples but received no response and nothing changed. They also give very short shrift to some areas with hardly any streetviews at all.

>5. Montero mashed it?

not bad

>6. Montero mangles it?

frightening
Simplicity...at what price?!

Could not agree more! An often overlooked gem.

But in addition to your very justified kudos, I want to mention three additional attractions of this restaurant.

They have a tasting menu, that I believe is one of the most accomplished in the city. Not in terms of bells and whistles, but just astonishingly wonderful flavors of the type you describe...each course a hymn to the excellence of the ingredients, incarnated with verve and imagination. It changes seasonally and is well worth experiencing. Great value and an excellent showcase of Chef Tracey's considerable artistry.

Second, the doughnuts are both addictive and inspired. They redefine the genre with an alchemist's brilliance with the sugar and seasoning. They deserve inclusion in your pantheon of recommended dishes.

Rienne Connelly deserves mention for her vast knowledge of cheese and the excellent variety and quality she sources for the restaurant, as well as her ability to work with the indeed accomplished Greg Majors (the Wine Director) to pair bespoke cheeses with a variety of wines.

I only wish PA restaurants doubled the retail price. They must buy their wines at retail from State stores thanks to our archaic system, thus the price often is four or five times State store retail.

Sometimes it's even worse; I have seen $15 retail wines at over $100 in PA restaurants.

We were regulars at Craft and heard from friends that they had been and the service was dicey. I have always found the food at Craft extraordinary but must confess that flawed service can ruin a good tasting meal.
This is one of our go-to places on visits to NY. Unpretentious and thoroughly delectable.

Salt Bistro in Boulder, CO focuses on local wines. So much so that they list wines from anywhere else as imports. Almost all the wines on the list are under $50 and the local wines offer the best deals.
Call me unemployed, but this all sounds way too expensive for street food.

Though we can't compete with NYC on number of great places to drink great wine we do have some real gems that offer fascinating wines at teeny, tiny mark ups.

We are really lucky to have Secco Wine Bar, their list changes daily and they always have a secret stash open...some examples AND their prices...

Urki Getariako Txakolina $8 glass-$34 bottle
Boulay Sancerr $37 bottle
Cistercensi Rusticum $40 !!!!
Chat. le Puy $50 bottle
Buondonno Chianti $33
Dom. Pelle Menetou-Salon Rouge $35
Larmandier Champagne $80

Also the other crazy place is Enotecca Sogno with even un-stupid marke ups, here are some of their under $50 wines...

Foradori Teroldego, 2008Trentino-Alto Adige $36
Isole e Olena Chianti Classico, 2008Tuscany $36
G.D. Vajra Dolcetto Coste E Fossati, 2008Piedmont $38
Castello dei Rampolla Chianti Classico, 2008Tuscany $38
Castello di Lucignano Il Solissimo, 2000Tuscany $38
Occhipinti SP68 Sicilia Rosso, 2009Sicily $38
Mastro Janni Rosso di Montalcino, 2008Tuscany $40
Casanova di Neri Rosso di Casanova di Neri, 2008 Tuscany $40
Felsina Chianti Classico Riserva, 2006Tuscany$42
Uccelliera Rosso di Montalcino, 2007Tuscany$44
Paitin Barbaresco Serra, 2005Piedmont$45
Vietti Barbera d'Alba Scarrone, 2007Piedmont$46
Salvatore Molettieri Taurasi, 2002Campania$48
Paolo Bea San Valentino, 2006Umbria$48
Orsolani Carema, 2004Piedmont$48
Sperino Uvaggio Coste della Sesia Rosso, 2006 Piedmont$48
Antonio Caggiano Taurasi, 2002Campania$49
Occhipinti Il Frappato Sicilia, 2008Sicily$52

And they do free corkage on Tuesday. For any other reason to relocate to Richmond...cheap-awesome wine!
richmondwineculture.wordpress.com

I love Craft, and this review reflects the many reasons why.  The food is so consistently perfect in preparation and quality.  We have appreciated the comfortably luxurious room as well as the gracious service many times.  Craft became our "special occasion" restaurant for the last 10 years, first in NYC and now Dallas.  We were fortunate enough to be at Craft the night the restaurant won the James Beard award.  Chef came in the restaurant jubilant and bought champagne for the restaurant.  It was really cool to see his well-earned excitement, and I'm thrilled that Craft continues to thrive.
I've never understood the problem with elbows on the table. I find it much more offensive for diners to hide their hands on the lap. What are they doing down there? It looks suspicious.
Go Dale, you suave dude!

Try my Wine Shop At Home selections. Want suggentions, have questions, contact me. We have a great selection all under $50 for any vinotype!
